text: to avoid the Burmese army this rebel
camp is in one of the most remote parts
of the jungle here in the northern part
of Shan State in order to get there you
have to travel on the back of motorbikes
along awful dirt tracks like this one
and then walk the final part into the
camp this is the training camp of the
tang National Liberation Army or Thien
la the tank like all of Myanmar's
minority ethnic groups have long wanted
greater control over their own affairs
under a military dictatorship that's a
non-starter so for as long as anyone can
remember
there have been Burmese rebel uprisings
many of the fighters like mine autumn I
decided to join up after tasting army
brutality at first hand as are the t nla
came to our village to carry out drug
eradication and then the Burmese army
arrived and I fought the villagers ran
away in the Burmese soldiers broke into
our houses and took everything they
could even small amounts of money the
Tang rebels are no Saints themselves
they admit forcibly recruiting local
villagers and we see new fighters being
trained who are clearly children not men
over time most of Myanmar's ethnic
conflicts have ground to a halt but
there are still regular clashes with the
army near here Nambu i'm told out in
july for tank rebels were killed and 28
soldiers beam into usually tuna when the
old town rebel group made a ceasefire
agreement in 1991 nothing was formalized
about what would happen next
so things dragged on until the Burmese
army disbanded them in 2005 we formed
the Thien la because we learned that
each ethnic group needed its own army so
you had got 9 10 11 12
so this is 13 bags of opium this table
is covered with drugs that the rebels
have confiscated in the last few months
the region is awash with opium and
methamphetamine and the tank blamed both
the Burmese army and local militia this
package of opium has split so you can
see a little bit inside that's raw opium
they're using out local people here eat
that or smoke it or the whole package
can be sold on to be processed to make
heroin the Burmese government says the
signing of a national ceasefire will
lead on to talks on a new federal system
the Tang have heard it all before they
and Myanmar's other armed groups still
have to be convinced that the times
really are a-changin
Jonah Fischer BBC news in northern Shan
State
